bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Information that may be recorded in the registry

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of furthering safety in relation to regulated work and regulated products, the minister must designate a provincial safety manager as the registrar and must establish a registry to record the names of licensed contractors and former licensed contractors and any information required by this Act and the regulations, including the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each discipline defined in the regulations under section 2 (1) (c) in which each contractor is licensed to do regulated work;
the nature and scope of the regulated work a contractor is licensed to do and any terms and conditions imposed on the contractor or attached to their licences;
the status of their licences;
any compliance orders, monetary penalties or discipline orders issued to them, any convictions for offences under this Act and whether any amounts payable remain outstanding;
an address for each of them for the purpose of service of documents.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar is responsible for maintaining the registry and for carrying out any duties in respect of the registry under this Act.
The registrar may remove the name of any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a licensed contractor or former licensed contractor if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the licensed contractor or former licensed contractor is a corporation and the corporation is dissolved or struck off the register of companies, or
the licensed contractor or former licensed contractor is an individual and the individual dies or surrenders their licence;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a licensed contractor or a former licensed contractor if their licence is revoked or cancelled under a discipline order.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A record of a compliance order, monetary penalty or discipline order that has been complied with, and any other information recorded in the registry, may be removed in accordance with the regulations.

A person whose name is entered in the register under this section must provide the registrar with and keep the registrar informed of the person's current address for the purpose of service of documents.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the details of a compliance order other than the existence of an order and the date of issue;
details of a discipline order other than the existence of a discipline order issued against a person, the date of issue, the reason for issuing it and any sanction contained in the order;
personal financial information;

If members of the appeal board sit as a panel,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the panel has the jurisdiction of, and may exercise and perform the powers and duties of, the board, and
an order, decision or action of the panel is an order, decision or action of the board.

paragraph.paragraphtext: of the board, the decision of the chair governs, and
of a panel of the board, the decision of the chair of the panel governs.

section.marginalnote: Orders to facilitate just and timely resolutions

subsection.subsectiontext: The appeal board may make any order the board considers necessary to facilitate just and timely resolutions of appeals.
Without limiting subsection (1), the appeal board may make orders

paragraph.paragraphtext: requiring the parties to the appeal to file written submissions with the board in respect of all or any part of the proceeding,
respecting the filing of admissions by parties,
respecting disclosure, including, without limitation, prehearing examination of a party on oath or solemn affirmation or by affidavit,
respecting exchange of records by parties,
directing the joining of appeals, issues or parties, and

requiring the parties to attend a confidential, without prejudice, prehearing conference to discuss issues in the appeal and the possibility of simplifying or disposing of those issues, and for that purpose, the board may order that the conference not be open to the public.

subsection.subsectiontext: If an appellant fails to comply with an order made under this section, the appeal board may dismiss the appeal.

The appeal board may hear, consider or determine an appeal, or conduct any proceeding in an appeal, even though a party to an appeal under this Part fails to attend the proceeding, file or make submissions, make disclosure or exchange records, in accordance with an order of the board.

For the purposes of subsection (4), the appeal board may make any order the board considers appropriate in relation to the party referred to in that subsection, including, without limitation, restricting the party's continued participation in the appeal and the party's rights under section 58 (b) to (d).

paragraph.paragraphtext: to attend;
to take an oath or solemn affirmation;
to answer questions;
to produce the records or things in the person's custody or possession.

subsection.subsectiontext: In this section:

definition.def: means a written agreement between a person and the safety manager under this section in which an alternative approach to safety is substituted for a requirement under the Electrical Safety Act, the Elevating Devices Safety Act, the Gas Safety Act or the Power Engineers and Boiler and Pressure Vessel Safety Act, or the regulations under any of those Acts;

paragraph.paragraphtext: the chief inspector under the Electrical Safety Act;
the director under the Power Engineers and Boiler and Pressure Vessel Safety Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: The minister may make regulations the minister considers necessary in respect of pilot equivalent standards agreements including regulations authorizing a safety manager, on the request of a person, to enter into a pilot equivalent standards agreement on behalf of the government with the person if

paragraph.paragraphtext: the safety manager considers that the proposed alternative approach to safety or proposed use of a regulated product would be consistent with the objectives of the Electrical Safety Act, the Elevating Devices Safety Act, the Gas Safety Act or the Power Engineers and Boiler and Pressure Vessel Safety Act, or the regulations under any of those Acts, and
the proposed alternative approach or proposed use would not create any additional risk of personal injury or damage to property,

section.subsandwich: and in all the circumstances the safety manager is satisfied that the pilot equivalent standards agreement should be issued.

subsection.subsectiontext: A pilot equivalent standards agreement must take the form of a written agreement between the safety manager and the applicant.
A pilot equivalent standards agreement may apply

paragraph.paragraphtext: to any area of British Columbia other than an area where a local government is responsible for administering electrical safety or gas safety, and
to more than one disciplines as defined under the Electrical Safety Act, the Elevating Devices Safety Act, the Gas Safety Act or the Power Engineers and Boiler and Pressure Vessel Safety Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: On the coming into force of section 33,

paragraph.paragraphtext: this section is repealed,
the regulations made under this section are repealed, and
a pilot equivalent standards agreement made under this section terminates.

subsection.subsectiontext: This Part is repealed on a date to be set by regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council.
